query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
1 Al fine de le sue parole il ladro 2 le mani alzò con amendue le fiche, 3 gridando: «Togli, Dio, ch’a te le squadro!».
query.result: 1 At the end of his words the thief 2 raised his hands with both the figs, 3 shouting: "Take it, God, that I throw them at you!".

4 From then on the serpents were friendly to me, 5 because one of them wrapped itself around his neck, 6 as if to say ‘I don’t want you to speak anymore’;
7 and another one wrapped itself around his arms, and bound him, 8 doubling itself in front of him, 9 so that he could not move them at all.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
10 Ahi Pistoia, Pistoia, ché non stanzi 11 d’incenerarti sì che più non duri, 12 poi che ’n mal fare il seme tuo avanzi?
13 Per tutt’ i cerchi de lo ’nferno scuri 14 non vidi spirto in Dio tanto superbo, 15 non quel che cadde a Tebe giù da’ muri.
query.result:
10 Ah Pistoia, Pistoia, why don’t you decide 11 to burn yourself to ashes so that you don’t last any longer, 12 since you surpass your seed in wrongdoing?
13 Throughout all the circles of the dark Hell 14 I have not seen a spirit so proud in God, 15 not even the one who fell from the walls down to Thebes.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
16 El si fuggì che non parlò più verbo; 17 e io vidi un centauro pien di rabbia 18 venir chiamando: «Ov’ è, ov’ è l’acerbo?».

Please translate literally into English.
19 Maremma non cred’ io che tante n’abbia, 20 quante bisce elli avea su per la groppa 21 infin ove comincia nostra labbia.
query.result: 19 I don’t think Maremma has so many, 20 as the snakes he had on his crupper 21 up to where our human form begins.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
22 Sovra le spalle, dietro da la coppa, 23 con l’ali aperte li giacea un draco; 24 e quello affuoca qualunque s’intoppa.

Please translate literally into English.
25 Lo mio maestro disse: «Questi è Caco, 26 che, sotto ’l sasso di monte Aventino, 27 di sangue fece spesse volte laco.
query.result: 25 My master said: "This is Cacus, 26 who, under the rock of Aventine Mount, 27 often made a pool of blood.

28 He does not go with his brothers on the same path, 29 because of the fraudulent theft he committed 30 of the great herd that he had nearby;
31 therefore his wicked deeds were stopped 32 under the club of Hercules, who perhaps 33 gave him a hundred blows, and he did not feel the ten".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
34 Mentre che sì parlava, ed el trascorse, 35 e tre spiriti venner sotto noi, 36 de’ quai né io né ’l duca mio s’accorse,
37 se non quando gridar: «Chi siete voi?»; 38 per che nostra novella si ristette, 39 e intendemmo pur ad essi poi.
query.result:
34 While he was speaking thus, and he passed by, 35 and three spirits came under us, 36 of whom neither I nor my guide became aware,
37 except when they shouted: "Who are you?"; 38 because of which our story was interrupted, 39 and then we paid attention only to them.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
40 Io non li conoscea; ma ei seguette, 41 come suol seguitar per alcun caso, 42 che l’un nomar un altro convenette,
43 dicendo: «Cianfa dove fia rimaso?»; 44 per ch’io, acciò che ’l duca stesse attento, 45 mi puosi ’l dito su dal mento al naso.
query.result:
40 I did not know them; but they continued, 41 as it usually happens by chance, 42 that one had to name another,
43 saying: "Where did Cianfa remain?"; 44 therefore, so that the guide would pay attention, 45 I put my finger from my chin to my nose.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
46 Se tu se’ or, lettore, a creder lento 47 ciò ch’io dirò, non sarà maraviglia, 48 ché io che ’l vidi, a pena il mi consento.
query.result: 46 If you, reader, are now slow to believe 47 what I will say, it will not be surprising, 48 because I who saw it, barely accept it myself.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
49 Com’ io tenea levate in lor le ciglia, 50 e un serpente con sei piè si lancia 51 dinanzi a l’uno, e tutto a lui s’appiglia.
query.result: 49 As I was keeping my eyes raised towards them, 50 a serpent with six feet darts 51 in front of one of them, and clings to him entirely.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
58 Ellera abbarbicata mai non fue 59 ad alber sì, come l’orribil fiera 60 per l’altrui membra avviticchiò le sue.
query.result: 58 Ivy was never so entwined 59 to a tree, as the horrible beast 60 entwined its own limbs around the other's body.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
61 Poi s’appiccar, come di calda cera 62 fossero stati, e mischiar lor colore, 63 né l’un né l’altro già parea quel ch’era:
64 come procede innanzi da l’ardore, 65 per lo papiro suso, un color bruno 66 che non è nero ancora e ’l bianco more.
query.result:
61 Then they stuck together, as if they had been 62 made of hot wax, and their colors mixed, 63 neither of them seemed to be what it was:
64 as a brown color proceeds upwards from the heat, 65 through the papyrus, 66 which is not yet black and the white dies.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
67 Li altri due ’l riguardavano, e ciascuno 68 gridava: «Omè, Agnel, come ti muti! 69 Vedi che già non se’ né due né uno».
query.result: 67 The other two were looking at him, and each one 68 was shouting: "Oh me, Agnello, how you are changing! 69 See that you are already neither two nor one".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
70 Già eran li due capi un divenuti, 71 quando n’apparver due figure miste 72 in una faccia, ov’ eran due perduti.
query.result: 70 The two heads had already become one, 71 when two figures appeared mixed 72 in one face, where two were lost.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
73 Fersi le braccia due di quattro liste; 74 le cosce con le gambe e ’l ventre e ’l casso 75 divenner membra che non fuor mai viste.

Please translate literally into English.
76 Ogne primaio aspetto ivi era casso: 77 due e nessun l’imagine perversa 78 parea; e tal sen gio con lento passo.

Please translate literally into English.
79 Come ’l ramarro sotto la gran fersa 80 dei dì canicular, cangiando sepe, 81 folgore par se la via attraversa,
82 sì pareva, venendo verso l’epe 83 de li altri due, un serpentello acceso, 84 livido e nero come gran di pepe;
85 e quella parte onde prima è preso 86 nostro alimento, a l’un di lor trafisse; 87 poi cadde giuso innanzi lui disteso.

Please translate literally into English.
88 Lo trafitto ’l mirò, ma nulla disse; 89 anzi, co’ piè fermati, sbadigliava 90 pur come sonno o febbre l’assalisse.

Please translate literally into English.
91 Elli ’l serpente e quei lui riguardava; 92 l’un per la piaga e l’altro per la bocca 93 fummavan forte, e ’l fummo si scontrava.

Please translate literally into English.
94 Taccia Lucano ormai là dov’ e’ tocca 95 del misero Sabello e di Nasidio, 96 e attenda a udir quel ch’or si scocca.
query.result: 94 Let Lucan now be silent where he touches 95 on the wretched Sabellus and Nasidius, 96 and pay attention to listen to what is now being shot.

97 Let Ovid be silent about Cadmus and Arethusa, 98 because if he, in his poetry, transforms the former into a serpent and the latter into a fountain, I do not envy him;
99 because he never transformed two natures face to face 100 so that both forms were ready to change their matter.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
103 Insieme si rispuosero a tai norme, 104 che ’l serpente la coda in forca fesse, 105 e ’l feruto ristrinse insieme l’orme.
query.result: 103 Together they responded to such rules, 104 that the serpent split its tail into a fork, 105 and the wounded one drew his footprints together.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
106 Le gambe con le cosce seco stesse 107 s’appiccar sì, che ’n poco la giuntura 108 non facea segno alcun che si paresse.
query.result: 106 His legs with his thighs stuck to themselves 107 so that in a short time the joint 108 did not show any sign that it was visible.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
109 Togliea la coda fessa la figura 110 che si perdeva là, e la sua pelle 111 si facea molle, e quella di là dura.
query.result: 109 The forked tail was taking the shape 110 that was being lost there, and its skin 111 was becoming soft, and that of the other hard.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
112 Io vidi intrar le braccia per l’ascelle, 113 e i due piè de la fiera, ch’eran corti, 114 tanto allungar quanto accorciavan quelle.
query.result: 112 I saw the arms enter through the armpits, 113 and the two feet of the beast, which were short, 114 lengthen as much as the others shortened.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
115 Poscia li piè di rietro, insieme attorti, 116 diventaron lo membro che l’uom cela, 117 e ’l misero del suo n’avea due porti.
query.result: 115 Then the hind feet, twisted together, 116 became the member that man conceals, 117 and the wretch had carried two of his own.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
118 Mentre che ’l fummo l’uno e l’altro vela 119 di color novo, e genera ’l pel suso 120 per l’una parte e da l’altra il dipela,
121 l’un si levò e l’altro cadde giuso, 122 non torcendo però le lucerne empie, 123 sotto le quai ciascun cambiava muso.
query.result:
118 While the smoke veils both of them 119 with a new color, and generates fur above 120 on one side and depilates it on the other,
121 one rose and the other fell down, 122 not turning their wicked eyes, however, 123 under which each one was changing face.

124 The one that was upright, drew it towards the temples, 125 and from the excessive matter that came there 126 the ears emerged from the smooth cheeks;
127 what did not run back and was retained 128 of that excess, made a nose for the face 129 and thickened the lips as much as was necessary.

130 The one that was lying down, thrusts its snout forward, 131 and retracts its ears into its head 132 as a snail does its horns;
133 and the tongue, which it had previously had united and ready 134 to speak, splits, and the forked one 135 closes up in the other; and the smoke stops.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
136 L’anima ch’era fiera divenuta, 137 suffolando si fugge per la valle, 138 e l’altro dietro a lui parlando sputa.
query.result: 136 The soul that had become fierce, 137 hissing, flees through the valley, 138 and the other spits behind it while speaking.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
139 Poscia li volse le novelle spalle, 140 e disse a l’altro: «I’ vo’ che Buoso corra, 141 com’ ho fatt’ io, carpon per questo calle».
query.result: 139 Then he turned his new shoulders, 140 and said to the other: "I want Buoso to run, 141 as I have done, on all fours along this path".

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
142 Così vid’ io la settima zavorra 143 mutare e trasmutare; e qui mi scusi 144 la novità se fior la penna abborra.
query.result: 142 Thus I saw the seventh ballast 143 change and transform; and here let the novelty excuse me 144 if my pen abhors the flower.

query.prompt:
Please translate literally into English.
145 E avvegna che li occhi miei confusi 146 fossero alquanto e l’animo smagato, 147 non poter quei fuggirsi tanto chiusi,
148 ch’i’ non scorgessi ben Puccio Sciancato; 149 ed era quel che sol, di tre compagni 150 che venner prima, non era mutato;
151 l’altr’ era quel che tu, Gaville, piagni.
